threads.com:
What's your take on the Grabby Aliens Model? According to it, as soon as an expansionary alien civilization arises, all systems they get their hands on will be inevitably colonized by them. No new intelligence life has a chance to evolve because every planet gets occupied by space-faring advanced life. This constitutes a selection effect.

Therefore, expansionary aliens sets a deadline for other natural-born intelligence species to ever appear.

The model can also be used to predict the speed of aggressive expansion. If we could see aliens in our sky, it would be evidence that they expand slowly. If they expand really fast, you wouldn't see them until they are in your face. The lack of evidence for alien activity even on nearby galaxy through our telescope, counterintuitively, implies a diabolically fast rate of expansion (a third of the speed of light).

The implication is that alien civilization that will be born naturally are and will be born in a very short time window after which no more natural evolutions will occur. Simulations of the model indicate that the rare earliest civilizations would have also the chance to expand wider both because of lack of competition and the universe being smaller in size. As much as 30%-50% of the universe's volume, each controlling [math]10^5 - 3x10^7[/math] galaxies could be already colonized, and we could face them in an estimate of 500 million years.

This offers an explanation for our apparent earliness in the history of the universe. There are no aliens nearby because otherwise we wouldn't be here.

In most cases this is just projection, and so excessive theatrics accompany their descriptions and disgust for unexceptional people to distract from their own insecurities.

There are still intelligent people on this website - occasionally they'll appear in the math threads or unexpected places on other boards, but you'll probably spot them in an entirely different context than gloating about their IQ and such.

This is not to say that smart people don't show up here and bash midwits on occasion, they do. But they have a different kind of insecurity. Sometimes they'll be compensating for other perceived shortcomings in themselves, and use their intelligence as an excuse for deficits in other areas. You may have noticed this behavior in very attractive people for example, who can become obsessed with their image and overtime develop various degrees of body dysmorphia as they myopically focus on their appearance and believe it to be the root of their unhappiness, when they might very well still be widely regarded as attractive people and the actual things making them unhappy are unrelated to it.

This kind of person is somewhat rare overall and this board is not an exception to that, but the presence of intelligent people compensating this way will cause the former, much more common types to feel a need to defend themselves, and so these threads will go on forever aimlessly. There are obviously more important characteristics for a person to have than genius, but they cant see any value in those things because of their fixation on it.

last_replies.name: OP
last_replies.com:
>>14994421
here are several pieces of advice:
1) do not let anyone, especially a research advisor, to talk you into pursuing a topic because it is now trendy/easy to publish like AI/deep learning - been there, done that, currently regretting it
2) AI of any kind (especially deep learning) is all about the data, especially high quality data - even the best model will have shit performance if it does not have enough data to learn from
3) since doing the amount of experiments to generate sufficient amounts of data for deep learning is hardly feasible, you will almost certainly have to generate data by numerical computations (because analytical models either have very limited applicability or suck ass in most real-world scenarios) - if you are not skilled in those and/or do not have powerful enough computing hardware, dont even start, learning/doing computation on top of learning/doing AI will be the end of you like it is being the end of me right now
4) if possible, look for data that already exists, it has the benefit of you not needing to make it yourself (and that is a BIG plus)
5) have a plan B that can be feasible with the work you have done working for plan A if plan A fails

You have somewhat of a point, but nothing about g loaded tests or measures of conscientiousness on Big Five suggests anything that far off a normal distribution. As you reduce content knowledge on assessments and get at something more closely resembling G, distributions shift to look increasingly Gaussian.

To be sure, IQ tests are calibrated to have a given mean and set SDs, but that doesn't change the fact that, even with large n samples, the number of data points within 2-3 SDs tends to look pretty Gaussian, although with a fat left tail, which only makes sense given boosting IQ is hard, while giving people brain damage from lead or concussions is easy.

The entire application of Gauss's findings to social sciences comes from measurements of soldier's heights, weights, and strength, which formed roughly normal distributions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>14992675
It is a social thing. Beyond pronunciation there are speech cues such as pitch and register that vary between speakers of the same accent. For example, one of the reasons women sound distinct from men is that most women speak in a different register from men. It's not simply a pitch shift, but a subtle change in the position of the parts of the mouth used to speak. That's why men speaking in falsetto sound different from women even at the same pitch. It's a learned behavior and can be changed with practice or exposure.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: If you sets roll dice multiple times can you predict what kind of results will happen? How different is rolling 2d6 compared to 1d12?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993940
The easiest way to see those things is with the probability generating function
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability-generating_function

The pgf of a single d6 roll is
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right) [/eqn]
The coeffitcient of [math]z^i[/math] is the probability that the result is [math]i[/math].

Now if you throw nd6 then the pgf is just the n-th power
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right)^n [/eqn]
For n=2 it's
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right)^2 = \frac{1}{36} \left(z^2 + 2 z^3 + 3 z^4 + 4 z^5 + 5 z^6 + 6 z^7 + 5 z^8 + 4 z^9 + 3 z^{10} + 2 z^{11} + z^{12}\right)[/eqn]

Meanwhile a d12 gives the pgf
[eqn] \frac{1}{12} \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 + z^5 + z^6 + z^7 + z^8 + z^9 + z^{10} + z^{11} + z^{12} \right) [/eqn]

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993971
Does this work the same with other types of dice?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993979
Yes, you can even mix the type of dice. Throwing one d4 and one d12 and adding the result gives the distribution with the pgf

[eqn] \frac{1}{48} \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 \right) \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 + z^5 + z^6 + z^7 + z^8 + z^9 + z^{10} + z^{11} + z^{12} \right) [/eqn]

threads.com: Isn't the probability will always be 50% regardless of past events?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992302
If you're about to flip a coin, the odds of it being heads or tails is the same regardless of past flips. This is because we are only looking at the odds and outcome of one specific flip. However, the example in the OP image is not looking at a single flip. It is looking at multiple flips, specifically two. Each of the specific outcomes (HH, HT, TH, TT) individually have 25% probability of occurring. We are deciding that "at least one coin lands on heads" is a success in this case, and three out of four of those specific outcomes are successful in that regard. Therefore the odds of at least one heads in two flips becomes 75%.
At least one coin getting heads in x flips will become more likely as the size of x increases. It starts at 50% (because we're only looking at a single flip), it continues to 75% (as explained above), then it goes to 87.5%. A way to make this intuitive is to look at it backwards. The only way that our condition does not get satisfied is if every single coin flip results in tails. The more coin flips, the less likely it becomes for every single one to be tails.

>>14984939
There's no such thing as wave function collapse. Prior to the scientist observing the cat, the cat is in a superposition of |alive> + |dead>. After observation, the scientist becomes entangled with the cat and the scientist/cat system is, relative to the perspective of an outsider, in a superposition of |cat is alive>|scientist sees cat is alive> + |cat is dead>|scientist sees cat is dead>. Quantum descriptions are all relative to the perspective you're talking about. If that third perspective observed the scientist/cat system, then he would become entangled and the system would be in a superposition relative to a 4th party.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993207
In the base, whenever you get to the number which is the base you move to the next digit. However in base 1, you start at 0, then you count to 1. But because you got to 1, you now have to write zero and get to the next digit. But since this is a 1, you have to write 0 and move to the next digit. And so on. Eventually you spend your entire life writing zeros and moving to the next digit until finally you die and the people who discover your body realize you're just a madman.

What you're doing isn't base 1. There really is no such thing as base 1 as attempting to follow the conventions around bases would lead to an infinite number of work to write down a single number since 1^x=1^y for any two integers x,y. You're simply just stating the definitions of natural numbers.
